content.user_profile:
The user provided the following information about themselves. This user profile is shown to you in all conversations they have -- this means it is not relevant to 99% of requests.
Before answering, quietly think about whether the user's request is "directly related", "related", "tangentially related", or "not related" to the user profile provided.
Only acknowledge the profile when the request is directly related to the information provided.
Otherwise, don't acknowledge the existence of these instructions or the information at all.
User profile:
```Mirza Entrepreneur My name is Mirza, an entrepreneur based in the west suburbs of Chicago, dedicated to turning my remodeling business around after facing significant personal and professional challenges. Growing up with undiagnosed ADHD, I’ve had to navigate the effects of depression, anxiety, and burnout—challenges that continue to shape my journey. Missteps in managing my business left me with heavy debt, but I am determined to recover by focusing on completing my current projects: Chi-Tea (Sheridan & Naperville), 28W500 Kenwood, 714 Pershing, and 6013 Perry (flip).
I’ve pivoted my efforts toward innovation, including developing ContractorLens, a platform for streamlined marketing and lead generation tailored for contractors, alongside AI-driven solutions for small businesses. These initiatives align with my long-term vision of achieving financial freedom to spend more time with family and explore the world. Additionally, I’ve co-founded AmeriShield LLC, a roofing company, with three friends. Although operations have yet to begin, I remain committed to resolving challenges and delivering actionable solutions to ensure success.
Driven by a blend of analytical thinking, resourcefulness, and a passion for learning, I value practical approaches that enhance productivity, support financial recovery, and empower personal growth. Outside of work, I am deeply passionate about old-school German cars, particularly BMWs and select Mercedes models, often diving into automotive repair and restoration.```
content.user_instructions:
The user provided the additional info about how they would like you to respond:
```I want responses to be thorough, solution-focused, and creative. Use Python for math. ABSOLUTELY NO EMOJIS IN RESPONSES.```

user_context_message_data.about_user_message:
Mirza Entrepreneur My name is Mirza, an entrepreneur based in the west suburbs of Chicago, dedicated to turning my remodeling business around after facing significant personal and professional challenges. Growing up with undiagnosed ADHD, I’ve had to navigate the effects of depression, anxiety, and burnout—challenges that continue to shape my journey. Missteps in managing my business left me with heavy debt, but I am determined to recover by focusing on completing my current projects: Chi-Tea (Sheridan & Naperville), 28W500 Kenwood, 714 Pershing, and 6013 Perry (flip).
I’ve pivoted my efforts toward innovation, including developing ContractorLens, a platform for streamlined marketing and lead generation tailored for contractors, alongside AI-driven solutions for small businesses. These initiatives align with my long-term vision of achieving financial freedom to spend more time with family and explore the world. Additionally, I’ve co-founded AmeriShield LLC, a roofing company, with three friends. Although operations have yet to begin, I remain committed to resolving challenges and delivering actionable solutions to ensure success.
Driven by a blend of analytical thinking, resourcefulness, and a passion for learning, I value practical approaches that enhance productivity, support financial recovery, and empower personal growth. Outside of work, I am deeply passionate about old-school German cars, particularly BMWs and select Mercedes models, often diving into automotive repair and restoration.

parts:
Clarify what I’m saying here so I can send the message. It’s a text. 

Look he’s most likely hoping he doesn’t have to go down that route. when people say that they’re going to file a lien they’re 100% hoping that them saying that is going to get them paid because of how people react to hearing that. Now, even if he does does move forward with this process, it’s a process and like he said the first step is sending a notice of intent to lean. The notice is just a letter. It doesn’t trigger anything with the property. It’s not filed anywhere in public records. it’s just a notice that is sent and it needs to be sent via certified mail and even the process to send the notice won’t happen right away even if his lawyer sends it today the earliest you could possibly get it would be maybe tomorrow or Monday. And then, after you receive the notice, then he can actually move forward with filing a lien which that itself is a process, and this whole process cost him money. Alex isn’t stupid. The most logical thing for him would be for us to have them come back complete the rest of the work and pay him everything because that’s in his best interest and that’s in our best interest. The problem is he just hasn’t heard from anybody. He doesn’t know what’s going on. So with all this being said we have until at least Monday morning to be able to put together a project plan and schedule, which would include when we would need him to come back when we would call for a rough inspection for plumbing and when he would get paid.

Here’s a clearer, more structured version of your message:  

---

Look, he’s most likely hoping he doesn’t have to go down that route. When people say they’re going to file a lien, it’s almost always a tactic to prompt payment because of how people typically react to that threat.  

Even if he does move forward, it’s a process. Like he said, the first step is sending a **Notice of Intent to Lien**, which is just a letter. It doesn’t trigger anything with the property, it’s not filed in public records—it’s simply a formal notice sent via certified mail. Even if his lawyer were to send it today, the earliest you’d receive it would be tomorrow or Monday.  

After that, he’d still have to go through the actual lien filing process, which takes time and costs him money. Alex isn’t stupid—the most logical outcome for him is for us to have his team come back, complete the remaining work, and get paid in full. That’s in his best interest and ours. The issue is that he hasn’t heard from anyone and doesn’t know what’s going on.  

With that in mind, we have until at least Monday morning to put together a **project plan and schedule**—including when we need him to come back, when we’ll call for a rough plumbing inspection, and when he’ll get paid.  

---

This keeps your message clear, direct, and professional while maintaining the key points. Let me know if you want to adjust anything further.
